greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T read by rows: T(i,0)=T(i,i)=1, T(i,j) = Sum_{k=1..floor(n/2)} T(i-2k, j-2k+1) for 1<=j<=i-1, where T(m,n) := 0 if m<0 or n<0.
comment: T(i+j,j) is the number of strings (s(1),...,s(m)) of nonnegative integers s(k) such that m<=i+1, s(m)=j and s(k)-s(k-1) is an odd positive integer for k=2,3,...,m.
T(i+j,j) is the number of compositions of numbers <=j using up to i parts, each an odd positive integer.
link: G. C. Greubel, Rows n = 0..100 of triangle, flattened
Clark Kimberling, Path-counting and Fibonacci numbers, Fib. Quart. 40 (4) (2002) 328-338, Example 2B.
maple: if j =0 or j = i then 1;
program: for(n=0,15, for(k=0,n, print1(T(n,k), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 23 2020
if n lt 0 or k lt 0 then return 0;
elif k eq 0 or k eq n then return 1;
end if; return T; end function;
[T(n,k): k in [0..n], n in [0..15]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 23 2020
else: return sum(T(n-2*j, k-2*j+1) for j in (1..floor(n/2)))
[[T(n, k) for k in (0..n)] for n in (0..15)] # _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 23 2020
if n<0 or k<0 then return 0;
elif k=0 or k=n then return 1;
else return Sum([1..Int(n/2)], j-> T(n-2*j, k-2*j+1));
Flat(List([0..15], n-> List([0..n], k-> T(n,k) ))); # _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 23 2020
xref: Infinitely many of the columns are (1, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, ..., Fibonacci numbers)
Essentially a reflected version of A011794.
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_, May 28 2000
